page.title: 02HISTORY OF STUBHAMPTON AREA
page.content: This upland wooded area was known to Neolithic man. An ancient highway, thought to be part of the Ridgeway, traverses the section east to west, with tumuli to be found at Stubhampton and a Barrow alongside the present C13 road. Later it became part of the great Cranborne Chase, renowned for its hunting and notorious for smuggling and poaching. King John acquired it through marriage in the 12th century. The Chase was divided into eight Walks, the Ranger of the West Walk living at West Lodge, a historic house lived in and added to in the 18th century by John Pitt MP. Sutton Hill Farm was one of those used by Anthony Huxtable, Rector of Sutton Waldron (1834-71), for his experiments in scientific farming.
